sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Set Suspicious Files as System Files Using Attrib.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the usage of attrib with the "+s" option to set scripts or executables located in suspicious locations as system files to hide them from users and make them unable to be deleted with simple rights. The rule limits the search to specific extensions and directories to avoid FPs

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Usage Of Web Request Commands And Cmdlets - ScriptBlock
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the use of various web request commands with commandline tools and Windows PowerShell cmdlets (including aliases) via PowerShell scriptblock logs

Adversaries may employ various system checks to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments.
This may include changing behaviors based on the results of checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox
Detects the presence of the keywords "Wscript", "Shell" and "Run" in the command, which could indicate a suspicious activity

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious New Instance Of An Office COM Object
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects an svchost process spawning an instance of an office application. This happens when the initial word application creates an instance of one of the Office COM objects such as 'Word.Application', 'Excel.Application', etc.
This can be used by malicious actors to create malicious Office documents with macros on the fly. (See vba2clr project in the references)

Adversaries may enumerate files and directories or may search in specific locations of a host or network share for certain information within a file system.
Adversaries may use the information from [File and Directory Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1083) during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors,
including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions.

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The macro defines multiple functions: `lVPi`, `vIpW`, `Document_Open`, `OFYH`, `yvid`, `NudJ`, `xQRg`, `SUkC`, `zIMa`, `aKfd`, `ttlJ` and `kvst`.

The `Document_Open` and `TextBox1_GotFocus` subroutines are triggered when the document is opened and when a textbox element gains focus, respectively. They both call functions `xQRg`, `yvid`, `lVPi`, `NudJ` and `OFYH`.

The `xQRg` function creates a folder using the `scripting.filesystemobject`. The folder path is constructed using the `ttlJ` and `aKfd` functions, which manipulate strings.

The `yvid` function creates a `MSXML2.DOMDocument` object. It then creates an element within the document, assigns a specific data type, and sets its text value. This text value appears to be Base64 encoded and is decoded using the `StrConv` function.

The `lVPi` function creates a `Scripting.FileSystemObject` and uses it to create a text file at a specific location. The path of this file is constructed by the `ttlJ` and `aKfd` functions, similar to `xQRg`. This file is then written to with data received as an argument.

The `NudJ` function performs similar operations as `lVPi`. It constructs a file path using `ttlJ` and `aKfd` functions, creates a file at the constructed path, and writes Base64 decoded data received as an argument.

The `OFYH` function constructs a string, likely a command, using the `ttlJ` and `aKfd` functions and executes it using the `vIpW` function.

The `vIpW` function creates a `WScript.Shell` object and utilizes it to open a file. The file path is constructed using the `ttlJ` and `aKfd` functions, similar to previous instances.

The `aKfd` function performs a bitwise XOR operation on two integers passed as parameters.

The `ttlJ` function converts an integer to its ASCII character representation using the `Chr` function.

The `kvst` function concatenates two strings received as parameters.

The `SUkC` and `zIMa` functions return long Base64 encoded strings. The encoded data is assigned to variables used within other functions.
